shelly disk) whose normal direction is such as to connect each
segment with the two segments that alternate with it in
each of the adjacent zones.

65  Now the addition of new zones, each similar to the
last, is a simple matter of <u>growth</u>; but the passages from the
simpler to the more complex plan marks an advance
in <u>development</u>; and this advance essentially consists
(here as elsewhere) in a progressive <u>differentiation of parts</u>.
When, with the vertical extension of the columnar segments,
the annular canal subdivides itself into two, the communications
between the successive zones no longer come off, as before, from
the annular canal, but from the intermediate portions
of the columnar cells; and instead of the two diverging
passages from each cell being inthe same plane, they lie
in different planes, alternating each other vertically.
up to this point, we observe little else than a multiplication
of parts vertically, as well as horizontally, and a
separation of connections that were previously confluent.
But in the highest stage of development, we find a marked
